articles.description: I use the draw.io desktop app to make diagrams for my website. I run it on an actual desktop, like Windows or macOS, but the asset pipeline that converts .drawio files, to .pdf, to .svg, and then to .svg again (but smaller) runs on Linux.
articles.title: Cracking Electron apps open

articles.author: mattpolito
articles.description:
# app/views/foos/_foo.html.erb

Foobity doo
<%= render "bar" %>
# app/views/dews/show.html.erb

Dewbie doo
<%= render "foos/foo" %>
"bar" partial cannot be found.
Missing partial dews/_bar, application/_bar
"bar" partial in the context it was called from. We declared the "foo" partial explicitly, so it did not error there. Since the "foo" partial calls the "bar" partial internally without being fully qualified, Rails is trying to find where it lives but cannot find it.
local_prefixes method and add the prefix where the partial lives.
class DewsController < ApplicationController
  def self.local_prefixes
    super << "foos"
  end
  
  ...
end

Rails can now find the sub-partial once you've added "foos" to the lookup context.
articles.title: Add partial lookup prefixes in Rails - #rails

Hot Corners, which are shortcuts activated by moving your pointer into a corner of the screen.
Mission Control, Launchpad, Lock Screen, Quick Note and a few others.
macOS Ventura 13, it can be found under System Settings->Desktop & Dock->Hot Corners
here.
articles.title: MacOS Hot Corners - #workflow

articles.author: andrewvogel
articles.description:
my last post about Geocoding, you'll notice that the value passed to the geocode sql function is an address. To properly pass that value, we need to make sure that we quote it for SQL land. 
ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute(<<~SQL)
  select
    rating
  from geocode('#{address}', 1)
SQL
address like 100 O'Connel Ave will cause the above to throw an error in the database
quote function from ActiveRecord, we properly quote our strings for SQL: 
quoted_address = ActiveRecord::Base.connection.quote(address)

ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute(<<~SQL)
  select
    rating
  from geocode(#{quoted_address}, 1)
SQL
https://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/ConnectionAdapters/Quoting.html#method-i-quote
articles.title: Quote a SQL Value in Rails - #rails

articles.author: andrewvogel
articles.description:
select
  result.rating,
  ST_X(result.geomout) as longitude,
  ST_Y(result.geomout) as latitude
from geocode('320 1st St N, Jacksonville Beach FL', 1) as result;

 rating |     longitude      |      latitude
--------+--------------------+--------------------
      1 | -81.39021163774713 | 30.291481272126084
(1 row)
https://postgis.net/docs/manual-3.3/postgis_installation.html#loading_extras_tiger_geocoder

h/t Mary Lee
articles.title: Geocode an Address in PostgreSQL with PostGIS - #sql

gem pristine <gem_name>. This command restores installed gems to their original, pristine state using the files stored in the gem cache.
here is some documentation.  
Matt Polito
articles.title: Gem pristine <gem_name> restores installed gems - #ruby

articles.author: viniciusnegrisolo
articles.description:
inputs_for accepts a skip_hidden attr which was very useful today. We have a has_many relationship that we are using <.inputs_for> to decompose the nested fields and as it was generating some hidden fields the style was breaking. Tailwind divide on the parent tag and those hidden fields were adding extra separation borders. A way to solve that was calling <.inputs_for twice as this:
<.inputs_for field={@form[:posts]} />
<.inputs_for :let={form} field={@form[:posts]} skip_hidden> <.input type="text" field={form[:title]} label="Title" />
articles.title: Skip hidden fields on Phoenix inputs_for - #elixir

articles.author: viniciusnegrisolo
articles.description:
divide classes that helps to add border between elements. So if you want to add a separator border for your children you can try:

03

articles.author: tonyyunker
articles.description:
uncomplicated firewall (ufw). You run ufw help and see that the entry for delete is 
delete RULE|NUM                 delete RULE
sudo ufw status, all you see is this
Status: active

To                         Action      From
--                         ------      ----
OpenSSH                    ALLOW       Anywhere
443                        ALLOW       Anywhere
OpenSSH (v6)               ALLOW       Anywhere (v6)
443 (v6)                   ALLOW       Anywhere (v6)
sudo ufw status numbered, which has the rule number in the left hand column.
Status: active

     To                         Action      From
     --                         ------      ----
[ 1] OpenSSH                    ALLOW IN    Anywhere
[ 2] 443                        ALLOW IN    Anywhere
[ 3] OpenSSH (v6)               ALLOW IN    Anywhere (v6)
[ 4] 443 (v6)                   ALLOW IN    Anywhere (v6)
sudo ufw delete 3.
articles.title: Delete A Rule In UFW - #devops

articles.author: craighafer
articles.description:
Rails.application.config.hosts << /.*\.ngrok\.app/
Rails.application.config.hosts << ".ngrok.app"

But it's still nice to know you can utilize regular expressions if needed!
articles.title: Rails config hosts accepts regular expressions - #rails

articles.author: gabrielreis
articles.description:
change method on migrations is great so you don't have to specify up and down and if you just want to execute a simple sql update on up then you can use the up_only method:
  def change
    add_column :products, :draft, :boolean, default: true
    
    up_only do
      execute "update products set draft = false"
    end
  end
articles.title: Using `up_only` in ActiveRecord migrations - #rails

articles.author: jackrosa
articles.description:
fetch_change/2. Simply pass the function a changeset, and the name of the column where you want to see the change.
changeset = change(%User{}, %{first_name: "John"})
|> fetch_change(:first_name)
# => "John"
articles.title: Directly fetch a change from a phoenix changeset - #elixir
